encodingDesc.projectDesc: The project focuses on digitising oral folktales from Ghana, specifically the Konkomba people, through different media. The project puts a body of oral folktales into writing and eventually makes them available as annotated, digitised narratives. It thus aims to make a contribution to visibilising this culture, which through processes of colonisation, the accompanying priviledging of written/print culture and Eurocentric/Western thinking has been marginalised.

body.head: ULAMBIDAAN SAVES HER COLLEAGUES FROM AN OLD LADY
body.p: (As told by Bilinyi Chiikpaab in Kutol on 18/03/2022)

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The following story details how a hyperactive girl saves her three colleagues from an angry old lady. The story has it that the old lady kills the girl’s colleagues with her magic wand because they refuse to give her firewood. Fortunately, the hyperactive girl tricks the old lady and kills her via the same magic wand, after which she resurrects her colleagues with it. As the storyteller spells out at the end of his rendition, the story warns against discriminating against people, especially people (and in the context of this story, kids) with disabilities or special needs. To watch the Likpakpaln narration click here.

div.head: Story
div.p: My next story is as follows:announces Bilinyi, who has obviously already told one or more stories during the storytelling session.

There lived a certain upininkpil who lived on the outskirts of a community. Her house was situated far from the rest of the community. She had the habit of begging firewood from young ladies whenever they were returning from lidɔbaal.

One day four girls, one of whom was ulambidaan, were returning from their firewood collecting expedition. As they were passing by her house, the upininkpil said: My grandchildren, please give me some firewood. But ulambidaan told her colleagues: Don’t give her; don’t give her. The others wanted to do otherwise but ulambidaan insisted so the girls refused to give the upininkpil the firewood.

On realising that the girls wouldn’t give her some of their firewood, the upininkpil deceived them and trapped them in her room. She then threatened that she was going to set the room ablaze and kill them. Having said this, she departed to get live coals from the main community. Ulambidaan took advantage of her departure and managed to open slightly the likapil the upininkpil had used as a door. She slid out, opened the room and let her colleagues out.

Now, the upininkpil had some pumpkins. After freeing her colleagues, ulambidaan selected four pumpkins of different sizes to correspond to her colleagues’ and her sizes – for the girls were of different sizes. Each of the four pumpkins therefore represented each girl. The smallest pumpkin represented ulambidaan. Of the four girls, she was the smallest in size. Ulambidaan then placed the four pumpkins in the room.

There was also a kapok tree near the upininkpil’s house. So after escaping from the room, the girls hid atop that tree. Unbeknownst to the upininkpil that they had escaped, she set the room ablaze on returning. She then remarked smugly: You’ll learn a bitter lesson today. You refused to give me your firewood. Well, I’ve taken possession of the firewood, and I’ll kill you as well.

As the room was burning, the biggest pumpkin exploded, kpiin! On hearing this, upininkpil said: Nhnn! The extra-large in size has exploded. After a while, the next pumpkin (in size) exploded, kpaaa! The upininkpil said smugly again: That’s the next in size. The third pumpkin soon followed with a medium-pitched explosion, pooo! The upininkpil got excited and said: Nhnn! Ulambidaan is next. The other three are dead. The last one soon exploded, kassiii!!! The upininkpil rejoiced and clapped in content. (The storyteller says this amidst clapping and gestures aimed at depicting the upininkpil’s body language and facial expressions.)The upininkpil remarked that the last explosion meant that ulambidaan was dead too. She was pleased that she had killed all the girls. (The storyteller utters the last sentence simultaneously with a member of his audience.)

The whole room soon burnt to the ground. But before upininkpil could jubilate any further, ulambidaan laughed in excitement and shouted in derision from the top of the kapok tree: Granny, granny, you’ve burnt down your room in vain. We’re unscathed.1
The upininkpil looked up and saw the four girls safely hiding in the tree. She then ran into her room, picked her magical kibeek, returned to the foot of the tree and started playing.
(The storyteller briefly teaches his audience the musical interlude and proceeds thus:)
The upininkpil picked the kibeek, sat on the ground and started playing:
(Together with his audience, the storyteller sings while simultaneously demonstrating, with his hands, how the upininkpil played her kibeek.)
The extra-large sized girl fell from the tree and the upininkpil killed her with her lijuul of death – for she had both the lijuul of life and the lijuul of death.
After killing the first girl, she took the kibeek again:
(The storyteller breaks into song again and his audience join in. He sings while simultaneously demonstrating with his hands again.)
The next girl fell off the tree. Two girls were still on the tree – ulambidaan and another. So the upininkpil played her kibeek again:
The third girl fell off the tree; so ulambidaan was the last one on the tree. Upininkpil took her kibeek and started playing again:
Ulambidaan lost her balance but while falling, she managed to grab a branch and quickly climbed up the tree again. Upininkpil resumed playing her kibeek:
(The storyteller, together with his audience, starts singing again.)

Ulambidaan lost her balance again but while falling, she managed to grab a branch again. The upininkpil quickly dropped her kibeek and rushed to pull her down. Ulambidaan climbed up a little higher so the upininkpil decided to go after her. When she climbed the tree, ulambidaan climbed higher. The upininkpil pursued her further and she kept climbing higher, each time teasingly leaving her foot a few inches from the upininkpil in order to entice her to climb higher.
Having deceived the upininkpil to climb to the apex of the tree, she quickly jumped down, picked up the kibeek and also started playing:
The upininkpil fell off the tree and ulambidaan killed her with the lijuul of death. After that, she used the lijuul of life to resurrect her colleagues.

The funny thing was that, when the girls were departing home on that fateful day for the bush to collect firewood, they initially barred ulambidaan from going with them. Yet she was the one who saved them from danger. In life, never discriminate against anyone based on their age or personality trait. But for the ulambidaan, the girls would have died.(Bilinyi concludes his rendition with this moral lesson, assisted intermittently by one of his audience. He then adds:)
This is the meaning and end of my story.

p.hi: (After this, all clap and another person tells the next tale.)

item.gloss: In the Konkomba culture, just as pertains in other African cultures and several cultures across the globe, young people can address old women or old men as grandmother or grandfather out of respect – and not because of any blood ties. Thus, in the context of this story, “granny” has been used by the ulambidaan as a mark of respect and not because she and her colleagues are related to the old lady.

div.head: A Glossary of Likpakpaln Words and Phrases (or Expressions)

list.label: gbin gbin gbin gbin:
list.item: an ideophone that describes the sound of a local guitar.
list.label: kassiii:

item.gloss: the storyteller’s ideophone for a low-pitched explosion.

list.label: kibeek:
kpaaa:

item.gloss: the storyteller’s ideophone for a relatively loud explosion.

list.label: kpiin:

item.gloss: a Likpakpaln ideophone for an extremely loud explosion.

list.label: lidɔbaal (aka idɔbu):

item.gloss: : the act of collecting firewood from the bush or forest.

list.label: lijuul:

item.gloss: Likpakpaln word for a magic wand or a tail – mostly, of an animal. Lijuul is one of the homonyms in Likpakpaln. Though it generally refers to the tail of something (most often an animal), it also refers to a magic wand that possesses supernatural powers to accomplish various tasks. It is often made from the tail of an animal. So in the context of this story, lijuul is a magic wand. The plural form of lijuul is ŋijuu.

list.label: likapil (aka likapiil):

item.gloss: a woven detached, movable door made from elephant grass. It looks like a trap door, save it is not usually fastened permanently to a doorpost. It is normally manually lifted and placed in front of a doorway to prevent access into or out of a room.

list.label: nhnn:

item.gloss: a Likpakpaln ideophone for expressing joy or satisfaction at someone’s misfortune. It is usually employed in situations where the user believes that the other person deserves a misfortune that befalls him or her.

list.label: pooo:

item.gloss: the storyteller’s ideophone for a medium-pitched explosion.

list.label: Sagnaa:

item.gloss: the name of the fairy (or spirit) the old lady in this story summons to throw the girls down from the kapok tree

list.label: ulambidaan:

item.gloss: a person who is hyperactive and derives joy from making fun of others. Transliterated as “the tongue’s owner,” it is a Likpakpaln body metaphor used to describe people who are restless in speech and action but who hardly attach any seriousness to whatever they do or to life in general.

list.label: upininkpil:

item.gloss: : Likpakpaln word for an old lady or old woman. The plural form is bipininkpiib.
